speaker: Unknown
message: IVM

speaker: Amit Varma
message: People who talk about the great potential India has and how we are becoming a younger country and we have this demographic dividend and so on, miss one important and depressing point. As a society, we actually suppress the potential of half our population. Women in this country are treated as second class citizens. They are not empowered in their childhood and are often educated less or worse than their brothers. They are forced to conform to roles that destroy their potential. In fact, they're looked upon more as property than as people. And when women speak up about this, they face an amazing amount of anger from men. Anger. Where is this anger coming from?

speaker: Unknown
message: Welcome to the scene and the unseen our weekly podcast on economics, politics and behavioral science. Please welcome your host, Amit Badma.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Welcome to the scene and the unseen. When I first asked the remarkable other team, it's good to join me on this episode. I told her the subject would be misogyny in entertainment and Indian society. Aditi said she wanted a different title. She suggested claiming our space. My subject was a lament, but hers was also a call to action and couldn't have been more appropriate. While we were chatting about it at the IBM podcast studio, one of the producers, Swati Bakshi, also got involved and shared some of her insights. So we improvised and asked her to also be a guest on the show. Swati is a former journalist who now works as a producer at IBM and will be taking over producing the show from Abbas Momen, whom you heard in the last episode, who is leaving the scene and the unseen to take over as producer of Cyrus Broach's fantastic show, Cyrus Says. I tried to convince Abbas to stay, but he simply doesn't agree that I'm funnier than Cyrus. Go figure. Anyway, I had an enlightening conversation with Aditi and Swati. But before we get to that, let's take a commercial break. If this happens to be the only podcast you listen to, well, you need to listen to some more. Check out the ones from IBM podcast who co produced the show with me. Go to IBM podcast.com or download the IBM app and you'll find a host of great Indian podcasts that cover every subject you could think of. From the magazine I edit, Pragati at ThinkPragati.com, there is the Pragati podcast hosted by Hamsini Hariharan and Pawan Srinath. There is a brilliant Hindi podcast, Puliyabazi, hosted by Pranay Koteswamy and Sourabh Chandra. And apart from these policy podcasts, IBM has shows that cover music, films, finance, sports, sci-fi, tech and the LGBT community all under one roof, or rather all in one app. So download the IBM podcast app today. Aditi and Swati, welcome to the show.

speaker: Unknown
message: Thank you, Amit. Hi, Amit. Thank you.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Aditi, in the last show that we did last week, where you spoke about the beginning of your journey as a stand up comedian, you said something which sort of a light bulb went off in my head. I mean, it shouldn't be a revelation. And I'm sure it's something that people like you take for granted. But you spoke about how part of the reason you came on your own as a comedian as someone who would stand and tell jokes was because you were in the girls college after a girl school, you went to St. Mary's in Pune and then to Sophia's in Bombay. And because there were girls all around you, you were actually able to get the confidence and were given the space to stand up and speak for yourself and build an audience. And your point was that if it was a coed environment, the boys would never have let that happen, because they want to be in charge of everything. And at that point, it struck me that there is no male comedian anywhere who would say that I got the chance to claim my space, because I was in an all boys school, because if I was in a coed environment, the girls wouldn't have let me. No male will ever say that, which kind of, you know, brings us to what I want to start this episode with is that when we speak about the role of men and women in society and how it is reflected in attitudes, we are starting at a very unequal spot, where women have to face a whole bunch of structural obstacles, which men are completely unaware of, like I was unaware that they could be such a thing till you mentioned it in the last episode when it's like, okay, another bulb goes off in your head. So I and you know, when I invited you to do this specific episode, and we spoke about it, the way I framed it was let's talk about misogyny and entertainment. And you said no, let's call it claiming your space, because that's a more positive way. And it's also broader. And, you know, we brought Swati into the show, because she had a whole bunch of thoughts on that from her experience. So let's talk about claiming your space. What has the journey been like?

speaker: Guest 1
message: A G and you know, that line you said was so true is that we're starting from a grossly unequal. I mean, the finishing the starting line is completely different when it comes to the different genders. And I sort of I remember being in an all girls school and I think I do this joke in my show right now, which is that in my family, we don't beat girls because they bruise easily. It's much easier to beat a little boy and be like, oh, he fell down from a cycle. That's why he has triangulation marks on his neck. And that always gets a huge laugh and a huge applause. But it also simply points out the fact that the treatment of girls and boys is unequal and is harmful for both girls and boys. I mean, girls, whether it's just being given a chance to be born, really is a is a sort of mathematical. So I think you're sort of you're playing Russian roulette from the womb. If you happen to be any other gender than male, and we cannot deny that whatever narrative that is currently running the world is male has been defined by heterosexual, to a very large extent, white men. Every other story then or every other voice that speaks up is then trying very hard to have themselves heard in a room that's already full of cacophony of one story that is trying to keep every other story down. So from the point of just being born to the point of having access to I mean, I keep thinking about I used to have this cousin who was really into cricket. And I remember because we were told no, no, no, only girls only play badminton, and boys will play cricket. And she I mean, unfortunately for her got breasts at the age of 12. And that was it. That was the end. No more cricket. No more cricket. No, Mithali Raj. I remember and this is an awkward, embarrassing thing to bring up literally within the first three minutes of this podcast. But I remember when I got my period, I hid it from my family for four months. And that included coming up with such weird devices to stop anyone from knowing because I knew that the moment I told them that I had my period, it would immediately be now sit with your legs closed. Don't talk loudly. Don't talk to boys. You can't be you know, doing all these things. I was terrified of the fact that my femaleness had suddenly asserted itself completely out of my control.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: That's almost incredible awareness for 11 or 12 year old or whatever it was.

speaker: Guest 1
message: Gee, I'd seen it just happen with I'd just seen it happen with so many of my classmates who would suddenly become demure, you know, during sports period, who would, you know, be sort of like, constantly be like, shoved aside and hushed aside. I just I was like, I can't let my childhood end. And I sort of, I mean, finally, I sort of came to terms with it four months later when it got found out. It's not even that I told anybody it got found out. And that was another hugely humiliating experience. Even though I come from a very liberal family, where you know, the other kind would be like better chocolate low now you're a woman. But what chocolate I wanted to run around I wanted to talk to boys I want to laugh loudly with my mouth open. I wanted to do those things. And I just knew at that age, that I was walking into a disadvantage. And I think that has sort of colored my perceptions of everything that I have done as an adult and as a woman.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And Swati I often say, you know, when I write about economics, I say from the economics perspective that India really inhabits three centuries at the same time, the 19th, the 20th and the 21st. And that's equally true of social attitudes that we inhabit those three centuries at the same time. And the journey for you in one sense has been starker for you know, those of us who are from Bombay or Delhi or whatever, because you actually come from Lucknow, and you've kind of made that journey from there. What has it been

speaker: Guest 2
message: like? It's quite a journey. And being in Lucknow was a entirely different experience, I would say that Lucknow University is still I think, like you said, is 18th century, I would not even say 19th. I mean, the way men behave with women there. And if you go to the university without wearing a suit or a dupatta, I mean, it's a scandal. And the way men look at you, they hound you, make comments on you, it's very, very normalized, it's quite normalized. And it is seen as a... So the level that it has been normalized is a problem. And it's not, it doesn't stop there. It seeps into every aspect of your life and everything that you do. So despite being highly educated and you know, working in one of the best organizations in the world, my experience has always been something that I would, you know, remember as an experience filled with discrimination on various levels and various different forms.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And just to set the context, what period are we talking about when you were in college

speaker: Guest 2
message: in Lucknow? It's still 2003.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Till 2003. And at what point does it sort of strike you that this is something that is not normal but normalized?

speaker: Guest 2
message: Because even at your home, you are told to present yourself in a particular way because you're a girl and you're grown up. I was, I mean, I became comfortable with my own body after I would say, you know, doing my post graduation in Delhi. Until then, it was a very turbulent phase because when I landed in Delhi from Lucknow, it was a completely different structure of, I would say, the structure of living, commuting, studying, everything was quite different from Lucknow. And it took a toll on my performance also, I remember. And that's like a blot on my resume till now. Until then, I was like a distinction holder. And then suddenly in DU, my percentage went down to 56%. It was like shattered. What was different? It was a cultural, I don't know, a cultural adjustment coming from a small town in India to a bigger town and then being a girl on your own. The kind of pace Delhi offered me, I was not prepared for that. And the kind of people around, I was not prepared for that. And it took me a lot of time to, you know, sync with the pace of the city. And that was obviously something that I had to understand. And then two years time was something that I took to understand that, to be in sync with myself and the city. So the city in itself is something, a big phenomena that decides how a woman would be. I don't know in other countries also, I think it's the same. But in India, it's very much a big factor that decides how you're going to move, till what time you're going to move, what subjects are you going to study if you're studying in a university. Because, you know, I remember in Lucknow University, the sociology department was notorious. And there were very few women opting for sociology because of that. One being myself, because my sister, elder sister who was studying in that department, she told me categorically not to take sociology because that department is notorious. So you imagine that how women do not, you know, make their choices, their choices are already being made.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: So here's my question for you. That fine, Lucknow and Delhi when you move there were like 18th century or 19th century India or whatever. And these attitudes were there and you just had to kind of adjust. But then you went on after that to work for the BBC, for example. Was that 21st century India?

speaker: Guest 2
message: It is. It is because BBC gave me a perspective. I was not that open minded, I would say to discuss certain things that the profession of journalism and the organisation gave me to think about. And the newsroom was a space where we used to discuss each and everything. And it's a good space to do that. Because there is no filters that we have to apply when we're discussing in meetings and all those things. But, you know, it took a lot of time for me there also to be comfortable talking about it. Like Aditi now can talk about her periods and I now can, but a few years down the line, I could not actually. So the organisation actually was something that offered me that space where I could open up and explore.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And would you say it is true of journalism or are there still those misogynistic attitudes creeping into journalism itself?

speaker: Guest 2
message: I would say true of journalism as a profession, definitely, because, you know, you are given certain assignments like reporting assignments where you are challenged by the space that you are accessing. And you have to understand that how you're going to do keeping yourself safe at the same time delivering what is required of you. So I would say journalism definitely made me a stronger person who is not only a woman, but a person.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: A stronger person by empowering you or challenging you?

speaker: Guest 2
message: Challenging me. Empowerment comes very late, you know, in Delhi, of course, when after 2012 also, when all these steps were taken that people would be dropped off, women would be dropped off with guards and all those things, that things, you think that a city can be secured like that, it's not possible at all, you cannot do that. So empowerment is something that I think our country needs to needs to think about, but challenging, of course, because if you are challenged, then you think about your own security, and then you devise ways of doing it. That is, again, is limiting your choices, because you don't have many choices to you know, to function and to make yourself secured at the same time.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And Mumbai, of course, is a world apart from Delhi. So you started doing, for example, open mics and stand up comedy in 2010. And on that, was it harder for you to be accepted?

speaker: Guest 1
message: Yeah, because the truth is also that we are taught we are inconveniences, our bodies are inconveniences, the space that we try to occupy is an inconvenience. Every time we speak up, it is an inconvenience. We are collateral damage to the narrative of the great man story. And we are side characters in our own story. And so I think that sense of like worthlessness, that's why it attaches itself to your psyche. That's why it attaches itself to our bodies. That's why I mean, marketers and advertisers can prey on our insecurities left, right and center. I personally do not remember looking at my own body because I was terrified. I was like, I don't know what is happening to my body as I grew up. Because I was like, I know that this is a problem. I know that this is going to like, restrict my space, this is going to make me invisible. And so it's going to make you invisible because people will see the body, not the person will see the body and not the person will not hear the words and that has not stopped. That has not stopped. I mean, I still am constantly getting you know, trash about what I wear on stage. You know, even the way I'm sure no male comedian ever does. No, no, no. You know, the kind of comments that that you see below my YouTube videos, which I've stopped looking at. But if you see the kind of comments below my YouTube videos, they will have a distinct color that I don't think any male comedian sees under their videos ever. The kind of abuse even if you say something ridiculous and you know, the kind of abuse that comes at you is always gendered. There is sexual abuse involved. There is rape threats involved. You know, there is general minimizing involved, which you don't see going to no matter how outspoken a man. When I started doing and I mean, I remember at the age of 10 when my I saw my brother was taking buses at the age of 10. And he had all these friends and he was going and hanging out with them and they would you know, form these cool gangs and they would go do cool things. And I remember I was dying to turn 10 so that I could take a bus and go meet my school friends and everything and I knew never turned 10 I turned 10 when I was 16 is when my mother finally allowed me to take a bus by myself. And that to then of course, you know, the but don't even put your bag in front, you know, and I mean, you see even today college girls going into trains into buses will have their bags will they have their backpacks in front of them, instead of on their backs, they'll have them in front, because it takes your breasts off the spoking stabbing market for that journey at least. I mean, and for like, I remember I started doing open mics. My mother was genuinely confused. She was like, you're going, you know, into these clubs and stuff like that. First of all, you're not even telling me what clubs these are. And then you come back late in the night. And you know, I think her problem was a little different, where she was like, you're not even drunk. What did you do at this club? If you've come back sober? This

speaker: Unknown
message: is terrifying. Did you not go to a club? So much for empowerment. She was sort of like

speaker: Guest 1
message: she was terrified. She was like, you know, are you not going to clubs? Oh, God, you're going to somewhere worse. And I was like, no, no, no, clubs only mom, clubs. But I know it took her so much longer to come to terms with the fact that I was doing this and that work required me to be out till say 1230 in the night. Even, you know, when I was sort of when I would say these ridiculous things on stage, that some might find sort of edgy or racy or whatever. I mean, luckily, I feel like as I mentioned earlier, that I've been blessed with super, super open minded parents. I think I am more conservative than my parents. I think I police myself a lot more than they imagine policing me. Because I am like, I'm like now they don't care. They don't say anything. Yeah, I have to be careful. Yeah. Who will marry me? You know, all those thoughts that that sometimes even our parents have not put into us have been ingrained into us by society. That, you know, if you if you speak too much, no man will ever find you attractive. This is my theory. The more a woman talks, the lesser men want to f**k her. And men do not know what to do with a woman they do not want

speaker: Unknown
message: to f**k. I have realized that men are like, I don't want to put my dick in her why she's

speaker: Guest 1
message: still talking like they get damn confused. And you have to and I think at the age of 32, I can finally say I'm okay with not fitting into any of the stereotypes that you have in your narrative of your story. I don't care if you are like confused by me. Because I am the hero of my own story. And it has taken me 32 years. I can't imagine I mean, I, I hated my 20s. I hated the insecurity of my 20s. I hated how it made me feel. And I my heart goes out to everybody who is navigating this world in their 20s with the level of unsurety with the fact that you are constantly being sort of minimized told that you are a side characters I said in somebody else's story. It just breaks my heart.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And what you said and all of us laugh when you said it just a few moments ago about men not knowing what to do with women that who are not sexual objects for them. We all laugh but the fact is that it's not actually a joke. It's actually just true. And earlier you mentioned, you know, edgy content. And it also strikes me that a lot of content which coming from a male comedian would not be considered edgy like sexual talk and so on or talk of body parts and all that is suddenly madly edgy if it's coming from a woman. Yeah. So how do you deal with that when that realization comes that everything that you say has that added layer of the context of your gender to it? How does that then affect the world? Do you try to sort of push the boundaries or do you censor yourself?

speaker: Guest 1
message: And for a very long time, so I've been doing comedy for seven, eight years now, I was clinically depressed for two during it, because I was terrified. I did not know what I was doing. And I knew that I didn't know how to do anything else. And I think the depression sort of, I mean, you know, sort of navigating through it, while simultaneously going on stage, of course, because girls got to make a living was...

speaker: Amit Varma
message: You got paid in garlic bread, you mentioned in the last episode.

speaker: Guest 1
message: What I meant was girls got to make an eating. But I know that I saw my peers travel much faster.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Your male peers.

speaker: Guest 1
message: Yes, my male peers travel much faster to a journey that was taking me much longer. Even today the market rewards male comedians because more spaces are male, because the biases against I mean, males, male comedians don't get your laugh is irritating. Your voice is irritating. She is making too many faces. I was like, this is my face. What do I do now? But that you don't see are problems for male comedians. But if you don't fit a certain type of role, when you are like, I mean, and unfortunately, or fortunately, the four or five stereotypes that we have of funny females is either you are grossly obese and disgusting to look at. And therefore your biggest shtick is how like you're just ugly and nobody will want to f**k you. And that is the sort of the even the hero will, you know, you had the tuntuns and the sort of these things where we just accompanied with... There was very little narrative for somebody who was the hero of her own story or the heroine of her own story. And I feel like I struggled with that for a very long time. I was like, what point of view am I writing from? And should I, am I worth, am I valid in saying all these things when I go into an audience? Does my personal story have any value? Because they don't want to hear it. They're a group of, you know, 200 people who've come to laugh. So why should I I mean, if I put myself out there, you know, what will the backlash be like? What will I hear that? And how long can I take that for?

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And did you ever then in that case face a conflict between your desire for validation, which of course, every artist wants, and your desire to also do the kind of work you want

speaker: Guest 1
message: to do and be true to yourself, whatever that may mean? And that actually has never stopped. That never stops. That is a continuous process that requires you to continuously engage your ego in this battle of like, I want to do this so badly. I want to tell my story. I want to hear you laugh so badly. But at the same time, I also want to protect myself. And I feel like with comedy, especially there was no precedent. There was nobody in India that was doing it before me. And there were no other women. So it was extremely lonely. And it was, you just sort of had to look within yourself to find...

speaker: Amit Varma
message: In a sense, like if eight guys are performing on a given night, and you're the only woman, you're in a sense like a freak, right? They're looking at you differently.

speaker: Guest 1
message: I mean, and even the green rooms and you know, environments, I mean, you I'm sure have been in all male environments. And what is now of course, legendarily known as locker room talk, right? You know, at some point, you're sitting there and you're hearing some men talk about another woman like that. And you're wondering, like you're looking out at the floor and wondering, Oh, what are they saying when I leave the room? And if so, then should I participate? Should I also participate in the abuse of this woman so that they will think I am cool?

speaker: Amit Varma
message: One of them.

speaker: Guest 1
message: That I am one of the guys. And how do you reconcile that? I am not one of the guys. I am not one of the guys. I have zero interest. Like I've realized dudes are way more drama than girls, by the way. This is what I have learned by interacting with groups of men is that they have way more drama in their lives.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Then what do you say that then being in these environments and you know, overhearing these conversations and finding out what men are really like, in a sense, as the solution due to some extent?

speaker: Guest 1
message: Extremely, extremely. And the pushback also, that's I'm saying no, like when I started doing comedy, I had nothing about men. I do not care about men from here to Pune. I have zero interest in men. But I constantly got, excuse me, female comedian, you hate men. I'm like, why do you make it so easy then?

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And I was watching a YouTube clip of one of your shows and I'd encourage my listeners to check out all the clips on YouTube, where you were speaking in some show in Australia, where you said that, you know, I'm, I've been introduced here as a comedian, but in India, I'm always introduced as a female comedian.

speaker: Guest 1
message: And you know, and that was the flip side of the empowerment, right? Is then they mollycoddle you, then they'll be like, you don't want to get raped? Okay, now take these company sanctioned cars. You are not going to save, you're not going to stop rape by wrapping women in bubble wrap. You are going to stop rape by educating rapists to not rape. But that seems to be something that I feel like, like our women's safety budget 100 crores on CCTV cameras. I was like, use that money to just talk to dudes about how women are

speaker: Guest 2
message: human beings. And that's the issue, this protection thing that why do women have to, they are the sufferers. They are, you know, fighting their way out. You should be saying we are the sufferers. And then we have to actually protect ourselves. I mean, in our own country where we are born and we are, I mean, we are the part of that productive population, we are contributing to the economy, we are the part of that intellectual section of this society. And we have to protect ourselves and find ways to not get raped and be molested and all those things. Why do we

speaker: Amit Varma
message: have to do that? It's incredibly perverse when you you frame it from the sense that if misogyny is a problem in India, surely the problem lies with the boys and not the girls. People who have the attitudes rather than the object of the attitudes. And you mentioned about, you know, women being a productive part of the workforce. And that's another thing I think that people sort of just take for granted that, you know, so many men will talk about growing the economy and this is our GDP growth rate and bang bang. But the point is that you treat half the people in the country as practically subhuman. And how many women in this country would actually be in the workforce and be productive? I'm not saying they're not productive if they're not in the workforce necessarily. But you know what I mean? They'd be far more fulfilled and contributing much more, but they're not allowed to.

speaker: Guest 1
message: You know, this is sort of one of those things where 80% of the problems in this country would really be solved if we tried to solve women's problems. Because obviously, as a gender are people and specially prone to seeing the effects and consequences of bad policies, bad public decision making. They are specially prone to suffering the consequences of that. If you started solving their problems one by one, you would have, like, I bet the number of problems that we could solve and the kind of conclusions that we could come to are much better. I mean, there is that fantastic Angela Saini book called inferior, which talks about how you know, I mean, biologically, it's been said that women are inferior to men physically. And, and then she talks about the biases in data collection, is that we have all known that a pain in your left arm is a sign of a heart attack. Turns out, it's mostly for men. For women, the signs are very different. But we have all been taught that it's a pain in your left arm. There have been people, women who have been having heart attacks and

speaker: Unknown
message: not known they're having heart attacks, because there's no pain, because they've been waiting

speaker: Guest 1
message: for their left arm to hurt. It is I mean, and I mean, science clearly is not sexist or corruptible. But the people who are practicing said science are just, the samples are male, are just are corruptible and sexist. I mean, not willingly, clearly, but I mean, the sort of the systemic oppression and ignoring of women in the mainstream has just has had, I mean, long term effects that we are going to see for the next six, eight generations.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: So now my big question is, are we, you know, now that we've sort of moved well into the 21st century and the social media and we are exposed to attitudes around the world, are we changing or not? But I'll come back to that after a quick commercial break.

speaker: Unknown
message: So welcome to another week on IVM. If you aren't following us on social media, please do where IVM podcasts on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. This week on Simplified in the Shorty, Naren and Shrikant simplify the phenomena of near death experiences with interesting cases and scientific theories. On Pragati, Pawan and Hamsini are joined by economic policy expert Yazaad Jal to discuss negative and positive rights. On the Scene and the Unseen, Amit Verma is joined by stand-up comedian Aditi Mittal and our production controller Swati to discuss misogyny and popular culture. On Pulyabazi, Saravan Pranai speak to Shruti Raj Gopalan about the meaning and importance of property rights in India. This week on Shunia One, we have Suchita Salman, founder and CEO of LBP, a local recommendations platform striving to discover all things new and old. On Hustle Science, Ranveer and Tejaswant speak to their buddy, tech entrepreneur and founder of Hello Inc, Andant Nathkarani to understand his coding craze and a lot more about his stories. And now, on to your shows.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Welcome back to the Scene and the Unseen. I'm chatting with Aditi and Swati about the broad subject of claiming your space, specifically talking about the misogyny in the industries that they are part of, which is entertainment, journalism and in Indian society in general. So my question to both of you is that, you know, in terms of technology and access to the world and so on, India's modernizing really fast, social media, we are, you know, the Me Too movement was all over the interwebs recently, and so on. And there is a lot more talk of feminism coming even from men, though one could argue that a lot of it is performative feminism and it's just, you know, empty virtue signaling without anything really behind it. Have things been changing in actual concrete terms in the way? Like, is it easier for women today than they were when you guys entered your respective professions?

speaker: Guest 2
message: It's difficult to say that it's easier and how it is happening is to be seen as well. Because if you see urban women like us who have opportunities, if they get educated, if they are alive and they get educated, they have opportunities, definitely, no matter how difficult the way is, but then how they are achieving that has to be seen. You know, every morning when I leave home, there is a cook who comes to cook for me and my husband, which means that my success somewhere is related to her unsuccess.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And the irony is that she is also relatively empowered compared to her peers.

speaker: Guest 2
message: Yes, yes. But this success, what we consider as success is actually is half hearted. And I don't think so that it can be seen as a success or achievement because there is a very, very small minuscule section which is being empowered, if at all. What about all those women who are not part of this, this league? Are we not going to think about them? Are we not going to do anything about them?

speaker: Amit Varma
message: And you've actually studied film studies.
